Walthol v. Johnson. [Friday, April 11th, 1800.] Declarations by the mortgagee, under whom the defendant claims, that the mortgage toas paid off are admissible evidence on the part of the plaintiff. Johnson brought detinue for a slave by the name of James, against Walthol in the District Court. Plea, non detinet; and issue. Upon the trial of the cause the defendant filed a bill of exceptions stating, that “ it was objected by the attorney for the defendant, that a declaration made by Ellender Willis under whom the defendant claims, after the negro in the writing annexed mentioned, *233had been sent by her to be sold to the defendant, that nothing was due thereon, should not go to the jury as evidence to prove, that nothing was due under the defeazance thereon endorsed; but, the Court considered it, as admissible, though not conclusive evidence.” The writing referred to, is in form a bill of sale, from Bough to the said Ellender. Willis for the negro James; but, there is an endorsement on it signed by the said Ellender Willis, which states, that Bough shall have the negro at any time on or before the first of September, 1793, by paying what is and shall appear justly due to the said Ellender Willis. This endorsement bears the same date with the bill of sale. Verdict and judgment for the plaintiff; whereupon Walthol appealed to this Court. Randolph, for the appellant.

Contended, that the witness was interested; and, there-' fore, that the judgment of the District Court was erroneous.

PER CUR.

There was nothing improper in submiting the evidence to the jury: But it might have been otherwise, if it had been gaming, usury or any other thing of that nature, which was to have been proved.

Judgment affirmed.*

[* See Vaughn's adm'r. v. Winckler's ex'r. 4 Munf. 136; Lewis v. Long, 3 Munf. 136; Canty v. Sumter, 2 Bay, 93; Frear v. Evertson, 20 Johns. R. 142; and Carr, J. in Ben et al. v. Peete, 2 Rand./ 547-549.]
